results.headline: Three Wise Men, Bumbling Their Way to Bethlehem

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Cant dels ocells

results.summary_short: The lovely and strange “Birdsong” (“El Cant dels Ocells”) is less a retelling of the Nativity story than a dream about it.

results.headline: Plus-Size Matriarch’s Stretch in the Slammer
results.display_title: Tyler Perry's Madea Goes to Jail

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's Madea Goes to Jail

results.summary_short: The best parts of “Madea Goes to Jail” are the title character’s motormouthed harangues. The rest of it is a fairly clumsy tale of sin and redemption.

results.headline: Family Memoir, Dictated From the Grave

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Must Read After My Death

results.summary_short: The documentary “Must Read After My Death” raises unsettling questions about the erosion of the private sphere.

results.headline: Teenage Boys in Pursuit of Pompoms

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fired Up!

results.summary_short: “Fired Up!” is at once funnier than it should be and more witless than it should have been.

results.headline: Forever Fashion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eleven Minutes

results.summary_short: “Eleven Minutes” reveals the fundamental silliness of fashion.

results.headline: Indian Soul

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delhi-6

results.summary_short: You don’t have to love “Delhi-6” to admire Rakeysh Omprakash Mehra, a director who has found a way to make personal films within Hindi cinema.

results.headline: Bearing Witness to Poland’s Pain

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Katyń

results.summary_short: “Katyn” is a powerful corrective to decades of distortion and forgetting in Polish history.

results.headline: Italians in Love

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moonstruck

results.summary_short: The moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie in “Moonstruck, and a lot of other things do too.

results.headline: Lurching Through a Life of Alcoholic Abandon

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Leaving Las Vegas

results.summary_short: “Leaving Las Vegas” works as a character study, pitilessly well observed and intimately familiar with its terrain.

results.headline: In Deepest Brooklyn, Affairs of the Heart

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Lovers

results.summary_short: Though it is set in the present, “Two Lovers” takes place in what often feels like an earlier incarnation of New York.

results.headline: Lesser-Known Mobsters, as Brutal as the Old Ones

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gomorrah

results.summary_short: “Gomorrah” is a corrosive and ferociously unsentimental fictional look at Italian organized crime.

results.headline: Oceans of Fun

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under the Sea 3D

results.summary_short: No computer-designed animatronic invention can begin to match the beauty and grace of the oceanic life photographed in “Under the Sea 3D.”

results.headline: A Slice of Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Friday the 13th

results.summary_short: The undying “Friday the 13th” franchise gets a surprisingly decent reboot in this stylish, playful example of the decapitated hottie genre.

results.headline: A Bank That Specializes in Payback (and Not the Kind With Interest)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The International

results.summary_short: “The International,” a sleek travelogue thriller, at least flirts with timeliness, winking at an angry and anxious public mood.

results.headline: When Retail Therapy Can’t Cure What Ails You

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Confessions of a Shopaholic

results.summary_short: Like the flailing American economy, “Confessions of a Shopaholic” wants to eat its cake and have its spiritual redemption too. (Talk about timing!)

results.headline: Awaiting Payback for Blowing the Whistle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Caller

results.summary_short: “The Caller” is a corporate crime drama that runs fatally amok.

results.headline: Oratory From the Streets: The Homeless Lift Their Voices
results.display_title: Great Speeches From a Dying World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Great Speeches From a Dying World

results.summary_short: “Great Speeches From a Dying World” is an unsettling documentary portrait gallery of nine homeless people living on the streets of Seattle.

results.headline: Cornered in a Parallel World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coraline

results.summary_short: “Coraline” lingers in an atmosphere that is creepy, wonderfully strange and full of feeling.

results.headline: A Comedy Far, Far Away

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fanboys

results.summary_short: There are enough good jokes in “Fanboys,” a road comedy about geeks on a “Star Wars”-related quest, to satisfy hard-core fans of that George Lucas franchise.

results.headline: Oscar Shorts, Low-Hype and Sweet
results.display_title: The 2009 Academy Award Nominated Short Films

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The 2009 Academy Award Nominated Short Films

results.summary_short: The 10 contending short films — five animated, five live-action — exhibit some virtues that their feature-length counterparts lack.
